metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: DSA Selection Sort
Selection Sort
The Selection Sort algorithm finds the lowest value in an array and moves it to the front of the array.
content.html: The Selection Sort algorithm finds the lowest value in an array and moves it to the front of the array.

content.text: Speed:
content.html: Speed:

content.text: The algorithm looks through the array again and again, moving the next lowest values to the front, until the array is sorted.
content.html: The algorithm looks through the array again and again, moving the next lowest values to the front, until the array is sorted.

content.text: How it works:
content.html: How it works:

content.text: Continue reading to fully understand the Selection Sort algorithm and how to implement it yourself.
content.html: Continue reading to fully understand the Selection Sort algorithm and how to implement it yourself.

content.text: Manual Run Through
Before we implement the Selection Sort algorithm in a programming language, let's manually run through a short array only one time, just to get the idea.
content.html: Before we implement the Selection Sort algorithm in a programming language, let's manually run through a short array only one time, just to get the idea.

content.text: Step 1: We start with an unsorted array.
content.html: Step 1: We start with an unsorted array.

content.code_html: [ 7, 12, 9, 11, 3]

content.text: Step 2: Go through the array, one value at a time. Which value is the lowest? 3, right?
content.html: Step 2: Go through the array, one value at a time. Which value is the lowest? 3, right?

content.code_html: [ 7, 12, 9, 11, 3]

content.text: Step 3: Move the lowest value 3 to the front of the array.
content.html: Step 3: Move the lowest value 3 to the front of the array.

content.code_html: [ 3, 7, 12, 9, 11]

content.text: Step 4: Look through the rest of the values, starting with 7. 7 is the lowest value, and already at the front of the array, so we don't need to move it.
content.html: Step 4: Look through the rest of the values, starting with 7. 7 is the lowest value, and already at the front of the array, so we don't need to move it.

content.code_html: [ 3, 7, 12, 9, 11]

content.text: Step 5: Look through the rest of the array: 12, 9 and 11. 9 is the lowest value.
content.html: Step 5: Look through the rest of the array: 12, 9 and 11. 9 is the lowest value.

content.code_html: [ 3, 7, 12, 9, 11]

content.text: Step 6: Move 9 to the front.
content.html: Step 6: Move 9 to the front.

content.code_html: [ 3, 7, 9, 12, 11]

content.text: Step 7: Looking at 12 and 11, 11 is the lowest.
content.html: Step 7: Looking at 12 and 11, 11 is the lowest.

content.code_html: [ 3, 7, 9, 12, 11]

content.text: Step 8: Move it to the front.
content.html: Step 8: Move it to the front.

content.code_html: [ 3, 7, 9, 11, 12]

content.text: Finally, the array is sorted.
content.html: Finally, the array is sorted.

content.text: Run the simulation below to see the steps above animated:
content.html: Run the simulation below to see the steps above animated:

content.text: Manual Run Through: What Happened?
We must understand what happened above to fully understand the algorithm, so that we can implement the algorithm in a programming language.
content.html: We must understand what happened above to fully understand the algorithm, so that we can implement the algorithm in a programming language.

content.text: Can you see what happened to the lowest value 3? In step 3, it has been moved to the start of the array, where it belongs, but at that step the rest of the array remains unsorted.
content.html: Can you see what happened to the lowest value 3? In step 3, it has been moved to the start of the array, where it belongs, but at that step the rest of the array remains unsorted.

content.text: So the Selection Sort algorithm must run through the array again and again, each time the next lowest value is moved in front of the unsorted part of the array, to its correct position. The sorting continues until the highest value 12 is left at the end of the array. This means that we need to run through the array 4 times, to sort the array of 5 values.
content.html: So the Selection Sort algorithm must run through the array again and again, each time the next lowest value is moved in front of the unsorted part of the array, to its correct position. The sorting continues until the highest value 12 is left at the end of the array. This means that we need to run through the array 4 times, to sort the array of 5 values.

content.text: And each time the algorithm runs through the array, the remaining unsorted part of the array becomes shorter.
content.html: And each time the algorithm runs through the array, the remaining unsorted part of the array becomes shorter.

content.text: We will now use what we have learned to implement the Selection Sort algorithm in a programming language.
content.html: We will now use what we have learned to implement the Selection Sort algorithm in a programming language.

content.text: Selection Sort Implementation
To implement the Selection Sort algorithm in a programming language, we need:
content.html: To implement the Selection Sort algorithm in a programming language, we need:

content.text: The resulting code looks like this:
content.html: The resulting code looks like this:

content.code_html:
my_array = [64, 34, 25, 5, 22, 11, 90, 12]

n = len(my_array)
for i in range(n-1):
    min_index = i
    for j in range(i+1, n):
        if my_array[j] < my_array[min_index]:
            min_index = j
    min_value = my_array.pop(min_index)
    my_array.insert(i, min_value)

print("Sorted array:", my_array)

content.text: Selection Sort Shifting Problem
The Selection Sort algorithm can be improved a little bit more.
content.html: The Selection Sort algorithm can be improved a little bit more.

content.text: In the code above, the lowest value element is removed, and then inserted in front of the array.
content.html: In the code above, the lowest value element is removed, and then inserted in front of the array.

content.text: Each time the next lowest value array element is removed, all following elements must be shifted one place down to make up for the removal.
content.html: Each time the next lowest value array element is removed, all following elements must be shifted one place down to make up for the removal.

content.text: These shifting operation takes a lot of time, and we are not even done yet! After the lowest value (5) is found and removed, it is inserted at the start of the array, causing all following values to shift one position up to make space for the new value, like the image below shows.
content.html: These shifting operation takes a lot of time, and we are not even done yet! After the lowest value (5) is found and removed, it is inserted at the start of the array, causing all following values to shift one position up to make space for the new value, like the image below shows.

content.text: Note: You will not see these shifting operations happening in the code if you are using a high level programming language such as Python or Java, but the shifting operations are still happening in the background. Such shifting operations require extra time for the computer to do, which can be a problem.
content.html: Note: You will not see these shifting operations happening in the code if you are using a high level programming language such as Python or Java, but the shifting operations are still happening in the background. Such shifting operations require extra time for the computer to do, which can be a problem.

content.text: Solution: Swap Values!
Instead of all the shifting, swap the lowest value (5) with the first value (64) like below.
content.html: Instead of all the shifting, swap the lowest value (5) with the first value (64) like below.

content.text: We can swap values like the image above shows because the lowest value ends up in the correct position, and it does not matter where we put the other value we are swapping with, because it is not sorted yet.
content.html: We can swap values like the image above shows because the lowest value ends up in the correct position, and it does not matter where we put the other value we are swapping with, because it is not sorted yet.

content.text: Here is a simulation that shows how this improved Selection Sort with swapping works:
content.html: Here is a simulation that shows how this improved Selection Sort with swapping works:

content.html: Speed:

content.html: Here is an implementation of the improved Selection Sort, using swapping:

content.code_html:
my_array = [64, 34, 25, 12, 22, 11, 90, 5]

n = len(my_array)
for i in range(n):
    min_index = i
    for j in range(i+1, n):
        if my_array[j] < my_array[min_index]:
            min_index = j   
    my_array[i], my_array[min_index] = my_array[min_index], my_array[i]

print("Sorted array:", my_array)

content.text: Selection Sort Time Complexity
For a general explanation of what time complexity is, visit this page .
content.html: For a general explanation of what time complexity is, visit this page.

content.text: For a more thorough and detailed explanation of Selection Sort time complexity, visit this page .
content.html: For a more thorough and detailed explanation of Selection Sort time complexity, visit this page.

content.text: Selection Sort sorts an array of n n values.
content.html: Selection Sort sorts an array of nn values.

content.text: On average, about n 2 n 2 elements are compared to find the lowest value in each loop.
content.html: On average, about n2n2 elements are compared to find the lowest value in each loop.

content.text: And Selection Sort must run the loop to find the lowest value approximately n n times.
content.html: And Selection Sort must run the loop to find the lowest value approximately nn times.

content.text: We get time complexity:
content.html: We get time complexity:
O(n2⋅n)=O(n2)––––––––––––––O(n2⋅n)=O(n2)__

content.text: The time complexity for the Selection Sort algorithm can be displayed in a graph like this:
content.html: The time complexity for the Selection Sort algorithm can be displayed in a graph like this:

content.text: As you can see, the run time is the same as for Bubble Sort: The run time increases really fast when the size of the array is increased.
content.html: As you can see, the run time is the same as for Bubble Sort: The run time increases really fast when the size of the array is increased.

content.text: Run the simulation below for different sized arrays.
content.html: Run the simulation below for different sized arrays.

content.text: The red dashed line represents the theoretical time complexity O ( n 2 ) O ( n 2 ) .
content.html: The red dashed line represents the theoretical time complexity O(n2)O(n2).

content.text: Blue crosses appear when you run the simulation. The blue crosses show how many operations are needed to sort an array of a certain size.
content.html: Blue crosses appear when you run the simulation. The blue crosses show how many operations are needed to sort an array of a certain size.

content.text: Set values: 300
content.html: 300

content.text: Random
Worst Case
Best Case
10 Random
Operations: 0
content.html: Operations: 0

content.text: The most significant difference from Bubble sort that we can notice in this simulation is that best and worst case is actually almost the same for Selection Sort ( O ( n 2 ) O ( n 2 ) ), but for Bubble Sort the best case runtime is only O ( n ) O ( n ) .
content.html: The most significant difference from Bubble sort that we can notice in this simulation is that best and worst case is actually almost the same for Selection Sort (O(n2)O(n2)), but for Bubble Sort the best case runtime is only O(n)O(n).

content.text: The difference in best and worst case for Selection Sort is mainly the number of swaps. In the best case scenario Selection Sort does not have to swap any of the values because the array is already sorted. And in the worst case scenario, where the array already sorted, but in the wrong order, so Selection Sort must do as many swaps as there are values in array.
content.html: The difference in best and worst case for Selection Sort is mainly the number of swaps. In the best case scenario Selection Sort does not have to swap any of the values because the array is already sorted. And in the worst case scenario, where the array already sorted, but in the wrong order, so Selection Sort must do as many swaps as there are values in array.
